description: Master level tools to recover lost code and debug history.

slides.title: git reflog
slides.content:
# The Time Machine ‚è≥

Git keeps a log of where your HEAD pointer has been.

Even if you delete a branch or hard reset a commit, the commit still exists in the `reflog` for a few weeks.

`git reflog` -> `git reset --hard HEAD@{5}`

slides.title: git bisect
slides.content:
# Binary Search üîé

Find a bug introduced in history.

1. `git bisect start`
2. `git bisect bad` (Current commit is broken)
3. `git bisect good v1.0` (Last known good version)

Git jumps to the middle. You test and say `bad` or `good` until the culprit is found.

slides.title: git blame
slides.content:
# Finger Pointing üëâ

See who wrote each line of a file and in which commit.

`git blame index.js`

Useful for understanding *why* a line was written (by reading the commit message).

slides.title: git submodule
slides.content:
# Inception ü§Ø

Keep a Git repository *inside* another Git repository.

`git submodule add https://github.com/lib/utils.git`

Useful for shared libraries, but adds complexity to cloning and updating.

slides.title: git worktree
slides.content:
# Multitasking üêô

Checkout multiple branches at the same time in different directories.

`git worktree add ../hotfix hotfix-branch`

Allows you to fix a bug without stashing/switching your main workspace.

slides.title: Debug Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which command uses binary search to find the specific commit that introduced a bug?

slides.title: Interactive Rebase
slides.content:
# Polishing History üíÖ

`git rebase -i HEAD~3`

Opens an editor allowing you to:
- **pick:** Keep commit.
- **squash:** Combine with previous.
- **edit:** Pause and change content.
- **drop:** Remove commit.

slides.title: git cherry-pick
slides.content:
# Precision ü§è

`git cherry-pick <commit-hash>`

Apply a specific commit from another branch onto your current branch.

Useful when you need a bug fix from `develop` but aren't ready to merge the whole branch.

slides.title: git revert
slides.content:
# Safe Undo ‚Ü©Ô∏è

Instead of deleting history (`reset`), it creates a NEW commit that does the opposite of the target commit.

`git revert <commit-hash>`

Safe for shared branches.

slides.title: Git Graph
slides.content:
# Visualization üï∏Ô∏è

`git log --graph --oneline --all`

Draws an ASCII graph of your branching history in the terminal.

(Or use GUI tools like GitKraken, Sourcetree).

slides.title: Tagging
slides.content:
# Bookmarks üìë

Mark specific points in history as important (releases).

`git tag v1.0.0`
`git push origin --tags`

Tags are immutable references.

slides.title: Undo Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which command undoes a commit by creating a NEW commit with the inverse changes?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Advanced Git üöÄ

Superpowers.

- **Reflog:** Recovery.
- **Bisect:** Debugging.
- **Worktree:** Parallel folders.
- **Submodules:** Nested repos.

## Next Steps
You have mastered **Git**! Keep coding!
